subject: HS2.0 Phase1 Implementation
commitMessage:
HS2.0 Phase1 Implementation

Change-Id: If33a939c8020dc4ed62ccc58f3b8e68f8c1b4c20
Signed-off-by: vinay kadam <vinay1.kadam@samsung.com>

comments.message:
Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

For the Hotspot feature, do we need to integrate it now?
I suggest to migrate RSA ConnMan patches before it and then integrate the new feature patch basing on it, and for the new feature patch, below is some of my suggestions:
1. Add more details description in the commit comments, for example, what's hotspot, what is it used for and so on.
2. It's better to divide the new feature patch into several small patches according to the functionality atoms? which will be more easier to review and maintain.
Thanks!

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I'd agree with Zhang that a good description of the functionality is needed and that the patch be split up into smaller parts making it easier to understand the various changes.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-2

Hi:
According to our Tizen Comms Development mode. the new feauture should happen at upstream firstly before we merge to Tizen.

So the right process is that you should discuss the new feature at ConnMan upstream. And submit patches there.

after the the patches are merged into ConnMan uptream we then can upgrade ConnMan and merge the new feature.

Only when the new feautre can't be accecpted by upstream and then we need to decide whether we need to handle that at Tizen firstly. But we need to try best to aovid it happening.
Thanks!

Patch Set 3:

Comments from Patrik & Zhang is considerable. However, according to Tizen 3.0 dev model, it doesn't make sense that first upstream, then Tizen.org. Plz, check the dev. model again.

Patch Set 3: -Code-Review

I'd disagree on the practical aspects of that consideration. By the time this HS2.0 feature is done, tizen.org should have been upgraded to 2.21 or later already - meaning there is less work doing the new feature upstream and then upgrading ConnMan only once for tizen.org. With development being done on 1.15, there is even more forward-porting effort next time an up to date version of ConnMan is considered and taken into use.
